Description: Pottery ring flask: with a globular body, long cylindrical neck and two vertical handles. It is made of an extremely hard, dense, gritty paste containing quantities of fine to coarse sand, and with many fine rectangular impressions on the surface from burnt-out organic matter. It was thrown in three parts, neck, front and back. The neck was inserted into body and body joined along side, the handles applied. The surface covered is with self slip and polished to reddish yellow. There is painted decoration of a guilloche pattern in black outline with red filling on body, and beneath the handles foliage of leaves and tendrils in red and black.
Curator's comments: Published: Bourriau, Pottery From The Nile Valley, no. 216 Africa in Antiquity vol.1, Brooklyn 1978, p.128 [Fig. 95]. Africa in Antiquity vol.2, Brooklyn 1978, p. 282 [225].
